results.title: Licence to kill (Special edition)
results.creator_credit: John Glen, Albert R. Broccoli, Michael G. Wilson, Danjaq and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “James Bond”.
The happy nuptials of James’ CIA buddy Felix Leiter (David Hedison) and bride-to-be Della are rudely interrupted when they embark on a mercy dash to capture drug lord Franz Sanchez (Robert Davi). Thanks to some aerial fishing though, their mission is successful and the parachuting groomsmen make it in time for the wedding. The happy couple are soon devastated however when Sanchez escapes and kills the bride and maims the groom as payback. This triggers best buddy James (Timothy Dalton) to relinquish his secret service status and licence to kill authority (Bond is under orders to complete another mission) as he embarks on a personal vendetta to revenge Sanchez’s brutality towards his friends. Ably assisted by ex-Army pilot Pam Bouvier (Carey Lowell), Bond flies into Isthmus City to infiltrate himself into Sanchez’s posse where he discovers a television evangelist (Wayne Newton) providing a front for cocaine dealing. Featuring a plethora of water inspired stunts earlier on in the film, the cast also includes Benicio Del Toro as a brooding henchman and Talisa Soto as Lupe Lamore, Sanchez’s mistress, eye candy, and source of jealousy for Bouvier. This was Timothy Dalton’s last appearance as Bond.

results.title: The Living daylights (Special edition)
results.creator_credit: John Glen, Albert R. Broccoli, Michael G. Wilson and Danjaq
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “James Bond”.
Touted as a possible replacement to the outgoing original Bond - Sean Connery - Timothy Dalton gave way to Roger Moore because he thought he looked too young for the role and didn’t appear until 14 years later in “The Living daylights”. Marking a more brutal instalment than usual, the film starts with a game of paintball gone wrong then moves to Czechoslovakia where Bond is entrusted with protecting the life of defecting former KGB agent Georgi Koskov (Jeroen Krabbe) who is being targeted by a sniper. When the sniper turns out to be a beautiful blonde cellist, Bond is content to wing her and pursue her later for further information. Safely back in the UK, Koskov is kidnapped and disappears, but not before he tells British Intelligence of a plot by fellow KGB agent General Leonid Pushkin (John Rhys-Davies) to assassinate British and American agents in a bid to start a nuclear war. 007 is ordered to carry out the termination issued against Pushkin, based on evidence which he considers dubious. When the name of an American arms dealer is mentioned, the plot thickens. Notable scenes include a particularly grisly death by automatic door and tobogganing on a cello case. It was also the last Bond film to use one of Ian Fleming’s original story titles. Cast also includes Maryam D’Abo, Joe Don Baker and Art Malik.

results.title: What's in a play: dramatic action
results.creator_credit: James Stinson and Film Associates of California
results.brief_description: Analyses dramatic action, a basic element of all plays, and illustrates it through the use of simple drama - a conflict between a salesman and a customer. Understanding dramatic action can help the student to analyse the structure of any play, and enchance their enjoyment of it.

results.title: Tony Allcock's art of bowls: putting it all together
results.creator_credit: David Hall, Mickey Shepherd and Pedigree Films
results.brief_description: Tony Allcock, British and international indoors and outdoors bowls champion since 1976, explains and demonstrates the basics of lawn bowls which, in his opnion, is all about line, length and luck. Dispelling the myth that bowls is a game for the “oldies”, Tony is assisted by his much younger colleague, Andrew Wills, who represents the growing interest by young people in this game of skill and patience. Forward swing, backward swing, estimating line and length correctly, use of body weight and movement, judging the pace of the green and speed of follow through are all examined in great depth. To demonstrate the various techniques, the pair then play two ends - a short jack and a long jack. This step by step guide all takes place in an indoor bowls club.

results.title: Goldeneye (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Martin Campbell, Barbara Broccoli, Michael G. Wilson, Danjaq and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “James Bond”.
Pierce Brosnan ignites the screen as the legendary James Bond in this explosive, thrill-packed adventure that hits the bulls-eye for nonstop excitement. When a deadly satellite weapon system falls into the wrong hands, only agent 007 can save the world from certain disaster. Cast includes Sean Bean, Izabella Scorupco and Famke Janssen.

results.title: Tone, Touch and Technique for the Young Pianist
results.creator_credit: Television Production Unit Centre for the Study of Higher Education and University of Melbourne
results.brief_description: Max Cooke brings to life the theories of posture, gesture and co-ordination, which lead to ease and beauty in piano playing. Explanations about muscular control, finger action, the role of the arms and sense of touch lead directly to exercises for specific aspects of performance, and these in their turn lead to the application of the skills acquired in actual music examples.

results.title: The Yellow leaf
results.creator_credit: Fergus McDonell, Julian Biggs and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A sympathetic study of an elderly widow, forced to leave her daughter’s household to live in a home for the aged. Shocked and disappointed at first, she overcomes her dejection when she fined that her new home offers congenial friends, new interests and a measure of independence she had not had before.

results.title: Tomorrow is maybe
results.creator_credit: Michael Halvajian and KRMA-TV (Television station : Denver, Colo.)
results.brief_description: Examines man’s dilemma of how to behave toward his environment. Is modern urban life, with its artificiality and ugly trappings of pollution and untrammelled usage of nature’s commodities, an instinctive protection against the alien silence and solitude of the wilderness? Narrated by Ben Aviary.

results.title: Tomorrow in their hands
results.brief_description: Illustrates some of the uses of non-military aid to developing nations. Film of actual aid projects in El Salvador, Bolivia, India, Pakistan, Thailand and Ethiopia is used to show that the major objectives of US aid to these nations depends largely on self-help and cooperation in each participating country. Narrated by Jason Robards.

results.title: Tomorrow's salmon
results.creator_credit: Michael Maltby, National Film Board of Canada and Nielsen-Ferns International
results.brief_description: The film describes the joint program of the Canadian and British Columbian governments to protect and strengthen stocks of Pacific salmon on which depend, either directly or indirectly, the jobs of 75,000 people and a $250 million industry. Well-documented and visually satisfying, the film alerts its audience to the necessity of sound conservation practices.

description_for_label: The film describes the joint program of the Canadian and British Columbian governments to protect and strengthen stocks of Pacific salmon on which depend, either directly or indirectly, the jobs of 75,000 people and a $250 million industry. Well-documented and visually satisfying, the film alerts its audience to the necessity of sound conservation practices.
